registry_entry.note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscopy with BAL and transbronchial biopsies for interstitial lung disease evaluation.
Patient: Natalie Reed, 53-year-old female with progressive dyspnea and bilateral ground-glass opacities.
Sedation: Moderate sedation with fentanyl and midazolam; native airway.
Bronchoscopic findings: Normal airways to subsegmental level.
Sampling: BAL performed in right middle lobe. Fluoroscopy-guided transbronchial biopsies (6 samples) obtained from right lower lobe lateral basal segment using standard forceps.
Complications: Mild bleeding controlled with iced saline; no pneumothorax on postprocedure CXR.
Disposition: Discharged home from recovery area.

note_text: OPERATIVE REPORT: The patient presented with diffuse parenchymal opacities. Following moderate sedation, the airways were inspected to the subsegmental level and found to be patent. A bronchoalveolar lavage was meticulously performed in the right middle lobe. Subsequently, fluoroscopic guidance facilitated the acquisition of six transbronchial biopsy specimens from the right lower lobe lateral basal segment using standard forceps. Hemostasis was achieved with cold saline lavage.

We performed a bronchoalveolar lavage in the right middle lobe. There was only mild bleeding which we stopped with iced saline. No pneumothorax was seen.

note_text:
Proc: Cryobiopsy ILD.
- ETT/GA.
- RLL basal segments target.
- Radial EBUS: Safe zone confirmed.
- 3x Cryobiopsy (1.9mm), 1x Forceps.
- Blocker used for hemostasis.
- No pneumo.

registry_entry.note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopy with transbronchial cryobiopsies for interstitial lung disease.
Patient: Carlos Rivera, 47-year-old male with suspected fibrotic ILD.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with endotracheal intubation.
Procedure details: Bronchoscope advanced to RLL; fluoroscopy and radial EBUS used to identify safe parenchymal target areas. Three cryobiopsies obtained from RLL basal segments using 1.9 mm cryoprobe and one standard forceps biopsy. Bronchial blocker placed prophylactically.
Complications: Mild bleeding controlled with temporary bronchial blocker inflation and iced saline. No pneumothorax on postprocedure CXR.
Disposition: Admitted overnight for observation.
registry_entry.primary_indication: Cryobiopsy for ILD diagnosis
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Reticular opacities and traction bronchiectasis in bilateral lower lobes
registry_entry.nav_rebus_view: Lung parenchyma without vessels by radial EBUS
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Transbronchial cryobiopsy for ILD
registry_entry.bronch_guidance: Fluoroscopy and radial EBUS guidance
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Histology including special stains for fibrosis and inflammation
registry_entry.bronch_immediate_complications: Mild bleeding controlled with bronchial blocker
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Cryobiopsy specimens adequate; final ILD diagnosis pending
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: ILD multidisciplinary conference review after pathology available

lines.description: Bronchoscopy; with transbronchial lung biopsy(s), single lobe

per_code.summary: Transbronchial cryobiopsies for parenchymal disease coded as TBLB.

global_comments: Removed 31645 (aspiration) as hemostasis/suctioning is integral to biopsy.

cpt_summary.description: Bronchoscopy with removal of foreign body

coding_review.rationale: Rigid bronchoscopy was performed solely to locate and remove an aspirated peanut from the bronchial tree of a 2-year-old, without additional biopsies, lavage, or stent work. This is classic use of 31635 (bronchoscopy with removal of foreign body). The diagnostic bronchoscopy and suctioning are inherent to 31635, so no separate bronchoscopy or BAL codes are added, and there is no documentation to support time-based moderate sedation billing.

note_text: PROCEDURE NARRATIVE: Under general anesthesia, the bronchoscope was advanced to the right lower lobe. To minimize hemorrhage risk, a prophylactic bronchial blocker was positioned. Radial EBUS interrogation confirmed a target area free of major vasculature. Three large tissue samples were acquired via a 1.9 mm cryoprobe, supplemented by one standard forceps biopsy. Hemostasis was managed via temporary balloon inflation.

note_text: We performed a bronchoscopy with cryobiopsy on Mr. Rivera to investigate his ILD. Under general anesthesia, we navigated to the right lower lobe. We used radial EBUS to ensure we weren't near large vessels. We took three biopsies using the freezing probe and one with standard forceps. A bronchial blocker was used to manage the mild bleeding that occurred. He is being admitted for observation.

registry_entry.note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopy with transbronchial cryobiopsy complicated by pneumothorax.
Patient: Megan Collins, 60-year-old female with suspected hypersensitivity pneumonitis.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with ETT.
Procedure details: Cryobiopsies obtained from left lower lobe basal segments using 1.9 mm cryoprobe (3 samples). Fluoroscopy used. After third biopsy, patient developed decreased breath sounds and rising airway pressures.
Complications: Left pneumothorax confirmed on fluoroscopy and ultrasound. A 14 Fr pigtail chest tube placed with immediate improvement.
Disposition: Admitted to step-down unit with chest tube to suction.
registry_entry.primary_indication: Cryobiopsy for suspected hypersensitivity pneumonitis
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Centrilobular nodules and mosaic attenuation
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Antigen avoidance and steroids with partial response
registry_entry.nav_rebus_view: Parenchymal target free of large vessels on radial EBUS
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Transbronchial cryobiopsy for ILD
registry_entry.bronch_guidance: Fluoroscopy and radial EBUS guidance
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Histology for HP pattern
registry_entry.pneumothorax_intervention: 14 Fr pigtail chest tube to suction
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Cryobiopsy adequate; final pathology pending
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Daily CXR; remove chest tube once air leak resolved and lung expanded

cpt_summary.description: Bronchoscopy with removal of foreign body

coding_review.rationale: Flexible bronchoscopy was used to remove a displaced dental crown from a right lower lobe bronchus. No separate diagnostic bronchoscopy, biopsy, or lavage is documented beyond what is required to find and retrieve the foreign body. CPT 31635 appropriately captures bronchoscopy with foreign-body removal; moderate sedation is mentioned but detailed start/stop times and independent observer documentation are not present, so separate 9915x moderate-sedation codes are not recommended.

note_text: OPERATIVE COMPLICATION NOTE: During transbronchial cryobiopsy of the left lower lobe for hypersensitivity pneumonitis, the patient developed acute hypotension and desaturation following the third pass. Fluoroscopy and bedside ultrasound confirmed a left-sided pneumothorax. A 14 French pigtail thoracostomy tube was immediately placed in the 5th intercostal space, resulting in prompt lung re-expansion and hemodynamic stabilization.

registry_entry.note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopy with transbronchial cryobiopsy complicated by pneumothorax.
Patient: Megan Collins, 60-year-old female with suspected hypersensitivity pneumonitis.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with ETT.
Procedure details: Cryobiopsies obtained from left lower lobe basal segments using 1.9 mm cryoprobe (3 samples). Fluoroscopy used. After third biopsy, patient developed decreased breath sounds and rising airway pressures.
Complications: Left pneumothorax confirmed on fluoroscopy and ultrasound. A 14 Fr pigtail chest tube placed with immediate improvement.
Disposition: Admitted to step-down unit with chest tube to suction.

note_text: The procedure began as a standard cryobiopsy for suspected hypersensitivity pneumonitis. We obtained three samples from the left lower lobe. Unfortunately, after the last sample, the patient developed a pneumothorax. We confirmed this with ultrasound and fluoroscopy and immediately placed a 14 French chest tube. The lung re-expanded and vitals normalized. She is admitted for chest tube management.

registry_entry.note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Robotic navigational bronchoscopy with radiofrequency ablation (RFA) of peripheral left lower lobe nodule.
Patient: Zachary Price, 66-year-old male with oligometastatic colorectal cancer to lung.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with ETT.
Navigation: Ion robotic platform used to access 12 mm LLL peripheral metastasis. Registration error 2.3 mm. Radial EBUS confirmed solid lesion; cone-beam CT confirmed tool-in-lesion.
Ablation: RFA probe advanced through working channel. Ablation performed at 50 W for 600 seconds with maximum temperature 90 degrees Celsius. Postablation cone-beam CT demonstrated satisfactory ablation zone with 5 mm margin.
Complications: Mild perilesional hemorrhage without hemodynamic compromise.
Disposition: Admitted overnight for observation.
registry_entry.primary_indication: Local ablation of oligometastatic colorectal metastasis to lung
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: 12 mm LLL peripheral nodule consistent with metastasis
registry_entry.lesion_location: Left lower lobe lateral basal segment
registry_entry.nav_rebus_view: Concentric radial EBUS view of lesion
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Bronchoscopic RF ablation of LLL metastasis
registry_entry.bronch_guidance: Robotic navigation, radial EBUS, cone-beam CT
registry_entry.ablation_complication_immediate: Minor perilesional hemorrhage without hemodynamic compromise
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Oligometastatic colorectal metastasis treated with bronchoscopic RFA
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Repeat CT chest in 3 months to assess ablation zone

cpt_summary.description: Bronchoscopy with removal of foreign body

coding_review.rationale: In this case, rigid bronchoscopy is performed under general anesthesia to remove a plastic foreign body from a mainstem bronchus in a child. The documentation describes careful inspection, retrieval of the object, and confirmation of clearance without additional diagnostic or therapeutic airway procedures. This is best represented by 31635 alone; no extra bronchoscopy, biopsy, or imaging codes are supported by the note.

note_text: OPERATIVE REPORT: Using the Ion robotic platform, the left lower lobe lateral basal segment was cannulated. A 12 mm nodule was localized. Confirmation was achieved via radial EBUS (solid lesion) and Cone-Beam CT (tool-in-lesion). Radiofrequency ablation was delivered via a dedicated probe at 50 Watts for 600 seconds. Post-ablation CBCT confirmed an adequate ablation zone encompassing the tumor with a safety margin.

note_text: We performed a robotic bronchoscopy to ablate a metastasis in Mr. Price's left lung. Using the Ion system and Cone-Beam CT, we perfectly targeted the 12mm nodule. We applied radiofrequency energy to destroy the tumor, reaching 90 degrees Celsius. The post-procedure scan showed we covered the whole tumor with a good margin. There was minimal bleeding and no complications.

coding_review.rationale: In this case, rigid bronchoscopy is performed under general anesthesia to remove a plastic foreign body from a mainstem bronchus in a child. The documentation describes careful inspection, retrieval of the object, and confirmation of clearance without additional diagnostic or therapeutic airway procedures. This is best represented by 31635 alone; no extra bronchoscopy, biopsy, or imaging codes are supported by the note.

Procedure: Robotic navigational bronchoscopy with thermal destruction (RFA).
Action: Ion platform navigated to LLL lesion. REBUS verified target. Thermal ablation executed at 50 W. Post-treatment imaging verified satisfactory necrosis zone.

registry_entry.note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Robotic navigational bronchoscopy with radiofrequency ablation (RFA) of peripheral left lower lobe nodule.
Patient: Zachary Price, 66-year-old male with oligometastatic colorectal cancer to lung.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with ETT.
Navigation: Ion robotic platform used to access 12 mm LLL peripheral metastasis. Registration error 2.3 mm. Radial EBUS confirmed solid lesion; cone-beam CT confirmed tool-in-lesion.
Ablation: RFA probe advanced through working channel. Ablation performed at 50 W for 600 seconds with maximum temperature 90 degrees Celsius. Postablation cone-beam CT demonstrated satisfactory ablation zone with 5 mm margin.
Complications: Mild perilesional hemorrhage without hemodynamic compromise.
Disposition: Admitted overnight for observation.
registry_entry.primary_indication: Local ablation of oligometastatic colorectal metastasis to lung
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: 12 mm LLL peripheral nodule consistent with metastasis

registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Repeat CT chest in 3 months to assess ablation zone

registry_entry.note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopic microwave ablation (MWA) of right upper lobe peripheral nodule.
Patient: Julia Bennett, 62-year-old female with solitary lung metastasis from renal cell carcinoma.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with ETT.
Navigation: superDimension EMN platform used to reach 18 mm RUL posterior segment nodule. Fluoroscopy and cone-beam CT confirmed tool-in-lesion.
Ablation: Microwave antenna advanced through extended working channel. Ablation performed with Emprint MWA system at 60 W for 420 seconds. Postablation imaging demonstrated adequate ablation zone with 8 mm margin.
Complications: Transient hemoptysis of approximately 15 mL, resolved spontaneously.
Disposition: Admitted overnight to telemetry.

coding_review.rationale: Bronchial thermoplasty is performed in a staged fashion with this session limited to the right lower lobe, with more than 50 radiofrequency activations documented via flexible bronchoscopy. note_text: PROCEDURE: The superDimension electromagnetic navigation system facilitated access to an 18 mm nodule in the RUL posterior segment. Radial EBUS imaging demonstrated an eccentric view. Tool-in-lesion was verified via Cone-Beam CT. Microwave ablation was executed using the Emprint system (60 Watts, 420 seconds). Immediate post-ablation imaging confirmed an 8mm ablative margin. Transient hemoptysis was noted and resolved spontaneously.

- Monarch robot -> RLL superior seg.

registry_entry.note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopic cryoablation of peripheral right lower lobe lesion.
Patient: Ryan Cooper, 69-year-old male with small presumed primary NSCLC not amenable to surgery.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with ETT.
Navigation: Monarch robotic platform used to reach 16 mm RLL superior segment lesion. Radial EBUS and cone-beam CT confirmed tool-in-lesion.
Ablation: Flexible cryoprobe advanced and three freeze-thaw cycles performed (each 300 seconds). Postablation cone-beam CT demonstrated ice ball encompassing lesion with 5 mm margin.
Complications: Mild transient hemoptysis and temporary increase in oxygen requirement; no pneumothorax.
Disposition: Admitted overnight to monitored bed.
registry_entry.primary_indication: Local ablation of early-stage NSCLC in nonoperative candidate
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: 16 mm RLL superior segment pulmonary nodule, PET-avid
registry_entry.nav_rebus_view: Concentric radial EBUS view
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Bronchoscopic cryoablation of NSCLC
registry_entry.bronch_guidance: Robotic navigation, radial EBUS, cone-beam CT
registry_entry.bronch_immediate_complications: Mild transient hemoptysis and increased oxygen requirement
registry_entry.ablation_complication_immediate: Mild hemoptysis and transient hypoxia, both resolved
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Early-stage NSCLC treated with bronchoscopic cryoablation
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: CT chest in 3 months to evaluate ablation zone; oncology follow-up

note_text: OPERATIVE SUMMARY: The Monarch robotic endoluminal system was utilized to navigate to a 16 mm lesion in the RLL superior segment. Confirmation of the target was established via radial EBUS and Cone-Beam CT. A flexible cryoprobe was deployed, and cryoablation was performed using a triple freeze-thaw protocol (300 seconds per freeze). Intraprocedural CBCT visualization demonstrated an ice ball completely engulfing the lesion with adequate margins.

registry_entry.note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopic cryoablation of peripheral right lower lobe lesion.
Patient: Ryan Cooper, 69-year-old male with small presumed primary NSCLC not amenable to surgery.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with ETT.
Navigation: Monarch robotic platform used to reach 16 mm RLL superior segment lesion. Radial EBUS and cone-beam CT confirmed tool-in-lesion.
Ablation: Flexible cryoprobe advanced and three freeze-thaw cycles performed (each 300 seconds). Postablation cone-beam CT demonstrated ice ball encompassing lesion with 5 mm margin.
Complications: Mild transient hemoptysis and temporary increase in oxygen requirement; no pneumothorax.
Disposition: Admitted overnight to monitored bed.

Resident Note
Procedure: Cryoablation
Steps:
1. GA/ETT.
2. Monarch robot nav to RLL.
3. REBUS/CBCT check.
4. Cryoprobe in.
5. 3 freezes, 5 mins each.
6. Ice ball seen on CT.
7. Mild bleeding/desat -> fixed.
Plan: Admit.

note_text: We treated Mr. Cooper's lung cancer with cryoablation today. Using the Monarch robot, we guided a freezing probe directly into the tumor in his right lower lobe. We froze the tumor three times for 5 minutes each. The CT scan during the procedure showed a nice ice ball covering the whole area. He had a bit of bleeding and needed some extra oxygen for a moment, but he is doing well now.

Transbronchial biopsies were obtained under fluoroscopic guidance (CPT 31628, 31627, 31654).

coding_review.rationale: The third bronchial thermoplasty session treats both upper lobes in the same encounter (right and left upper lobes). The prepatch data only carried 31660, so 31661 has been added to reflect treatment of a second lobe. Local 2025 fee-schedule data used here include full RVU/payment detail for 31660 but do not contain the facility RVU/payment fields for 31661, so those values are left null and should be verified against the current Medicare fee schedule if needed.

coding_review.rationale: The final note describes thoracoscopic evaluation of malignant pleural effusion with pleural biopsies and talc pleurodesis plus placement of a tunneled indwelling pleural catheter at the same session. In this setting, 32609 captures the thoracoscopic biopsy and pleurodesis, while 32550 separately describes creation of the tunneled pleural catheter. No separate thoracentesis code (32555) is reported because initial access and fluid evacuation are considered part of 32550 when an indwelling tunneled catheter is placed, and diagnostic thoracoscopy is bundled into the therapeutic thoracoscopic procedure.

cpt_summary.description: Thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies and pleurodesis
Insertion of indwelling tunneled pleural catheter with cuff

coding_review.rationale: The final note describes thoracoscopic evaluation of malignant pleural effusion with pleural biopsies and talc pleurodesis plus placement of a tunneled indwelling pleural catheter at the same session. In this setting, 32609 captures the thoracoscopic biopsy and pleurodesis, while 32550 separately describes creation of the tunneled pleural catheter. No separate thoracentesis code (32555) is reported because initial access and fluid evacuation are considered part of 32550 when an indwelling tunneled catheter is placed, and diagnostic thoracoscopy is bundled into the therapeutic thoracoscopic procedure.
